data.title: NY Mets sign Jose Martinez: 3 things to know about their latest addition
authors: Justin Toscano, North Jersey Media Group
data.meta_description: How could Jose Martinez help the Mets? Here are three things to know after the team signed the former Cardinals star.
data.text:
Since taking the job, Mets general manager Jared Porter, among other things, has emphasized a need to build roster depth.

"Those smaller decisions that you make are sometimes just as important as the big ones," Porter said during a recent interview with SiriusXM NHL Network Radio.

A potential example: The Mets on Thursday announced they signed Jose Martinez to a one-year contract. Martinez is a first baseman, outfielder and designated hitter whose bat greatly exceeds his defensive ability.

According to USA TODAY Sports' Bob Nightengale, Martinez is receiving a split contract that will pay him $1 million plus $500,000 in potential incentives if he makes the major league roster.

This move is not as flashy as acquiring Francisco Lindor and Carlos Carrasco, or potential signings of George Springer or Brad Hand. But can it help the Mets?

LINEUP: Projected Mets lineup, rotation after Francisco Lindor, Carlos Carrasco trade

It's possible.

Here are three things to know:

How Martinez could fit on big league roster

If you knew Martinez was a first baseman and outfielder, your first question was probably: How the heck does he fit on this team?

Fair.

The Mets have two first basemen in Pete Alonso and Dominic Smith. Martinez likely wouldn't play there.

In the outfield, metrics say he is not good. Per FanGraphs' defensive runs saved metric, Martinez has cost his team runs with his outfield defense in every year of his career that he's played there. And recently, president Sandy Alderson said it wouldn't be ideal to play Smith — who isn't a natural outfielder — in left field, so why would the Mets throw Martinez in the outfield?

Well, his value comes as a potential designated hitter — if the universal DH were to return — or bench bat.

If you take out a rough 2020, Martinez slashed .298/.363/.458 with 41 homers from 2016-19 with the Cardinals. Perhaps more importantly: Martinez, now 32, has a .915 OPS against lefties over his career, which would make him a valuable bench bat if the Mets had room.

NY METS: 3 thoughts on Francisco Lindor trade and where they stand in NL East

Organizational depth

Depth, depth, depth. Even as Alderson has discussed the Mets shopping in the gourmet aisle, he and Porter have pointed to trying to fill out the organization.

More specifically, Alderson in November said the Mets were thin in the upper minors. If he doesn't make the big league club, Martinez could be a veteran minor leaguer in their system, someone who could always be recalled if needed.

If you're looking at first base, the Mets may not have much of a plan past Alonso and Smith. They don't have any highly touted prospects who are first basemen —definitely no one who would be ready anytime soon.

Signing Martinez is a good way for the Mets to ensure they're covered at first base, even if he doesn't make the major league

Plus, this is low-risk for the Mets. Martinez's contract will only pay the $1 million if he makes the big league roster.

Why not give him a shot?

Part of a trade that looks bigger now

Randy Arozarena. That name ring a bell?

Well, Martinez was part of the deal you heard about all throughout last postseason. He and Arozarena went to the Rays in the trade.

It was, by no means, a blockbuster.

It just looks much bigger now because Arozarena took center stage and dominated during a postseason run, fueling the Rays to the World Series.
